message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: UAV swarms: research, challenges, and future directions
Paper Abstract: Abstract Unmanned Aerial Vehicle (UAV) swarms represent a transformative advancement in aerial robotics, leveraging collaborative autonomy to enhance operational capabilities. This paper provides a comprehensive exploration of UAV swarm infrastructure, recent research advancements, and diverse applications. Key areas such as coordinated path planning, task assignment, formation control, and security considerations are examined, highlighting how Artificial Intelligence (AI) and Machine Learning (ML) are integrated to improve decision-making and adaptability. Applications span civilian sectors, including entertainment, infrastructure inspection, and delivery services, as well as military applications in surveillance, combat support, and logistics. The paper addresses technical challenges, regulatory constraints, and ethical considerations, while outlining future directions focused on scalability, robustness, and societal integration. This review consolidates the evolving landscape of UAV swarms, identifying critical challenges and guiding future research endeavors.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity, entity_type: one of task/data/artifact/tool/concept/other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results, relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

I've performed a web search for "Machine learning" and retrieved comprehensive information. Here are the key findings:

## Overview

Machine learning (ML) is a field of study in artificial intelligence concerned with the development and study of statistical algorithms that can learn from data and generalise to unseen data, and thus perform tasks without explicit instructions.

## Main Learning Paradigms

Machine learning is commonly separated into three main learning paradigms: supervised learning, unsupervised learning and reinforcement learning.

## Applications

ML finds application in many fields, including natural language processing, computer vision, speech recognition, email filtering, agriculture, and medicine.

## Historical Development

The term machine learning was coined in 1959 by Arthur Samuel, an IBM employee and pioneer in the field of computer gaming and artificial intelligence.(no content)The earliest machine learning program was introduced in the 1950s when Arthur Samuel invented a computer program that calculated the winning chance in checkers for each side.

## Neural Networks and Deep Learning

In machine learning, a neural network or neural net (NN), also called artificial neural network (ANN), is a computational model inspired by the structure and functions of biological neural networks. A neural network consists of connected units or nodes called artificial neurons, which loosely model the neurons in the brain.(no content)Within a subdiscipline in machine learning, advances in the field of deep learning have allowed neural networks, a class of statistical algorithms, to surpass many previous machine learning approaches in performance.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about unmanned aerial vehicles:

## Definition and Basic Characteristics

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## How UAVs Work

UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles, and are capable of controlled, sustained level flight and powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## Historical Development

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, and in 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications, with over 237 identified ways that drones revolutionize business across 15 industries including agriculture, energy, construction, and mining.(no content)Civil uses include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, and delivery of medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions.

Based on the search results, here's comprehensive information about unmanned aerial vehicles:

## Definition and Basic Characteristics

An unmanned aerial vehicle (UAV), commonly known as a drone, is an aircraft with no human pilot, crew, or passengers on board, but rather is controlled remotely or is autonomous.

## How UAVs Work

UAVs include both autonomous drones and remotely piloted vehicles, and are capable of controlled, sustained level flight and powered by a jet, reciprocating, or electric engine.

## Historical Development

The earliest recorded use of an unmanned aerial vehicle for warfighting occurred in July 1849, with a balloon carrier in the first offensive use of air power in naval aviation, when Austrian forces besieging Venice attempted to launch some 200 incendiary balloons at the besieged city.(no content)In 2006, the United States Federal Aviation Administration allowed the usage of unmanned aerial vehicles inside civilian airspace with specific regulations, and in 2013, DJI released the first model of the Phantom drone.

## Applications

Unmanned aerial vehicles are used across the world for civilian, commercial, as well as military applications, with over 237 identified ways that drones revolutionize business across 15 industries including agriculture, energy, construction, and mining.(no content)Civil uses include aerial crop surveys, aerial photography, search and rescue, inspection of power lines and pipelines, and delivery of medical supplies to otherwise inaccessible regions.

Web search results for query: "Artificial intelligence"

Links: [{"title":"Artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial general intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_general_intelligence"},{"title":"Applications of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Applications_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Timeline of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Timeline_of_artificial_intelligence"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence in video games - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_in_video_games"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence visual art - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_art"},{"title":"Artificial Intelligence: A Modern Approach - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_Intelligence:_A_Modern_Approach"},{"title":"List of artificial intelligence films - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_artificial_intelligence_films"},{"title":"Artificial intelligence arms race - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Artificial_intelligence_arms_race"},{"title":"Ethics of artificial intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ethics_of_artificial_intelligence"}]

Here's a comprehensive overview of artificial intelligence based on the search results:

## Definition and Goals

Artificial intelligence is the capability of computational systems to perform tasks typically associated with human intelligence, such as learning, reasoning, problem-solving, perception, and decision-making.(no content)The traditional goals of AI research include learning, reasoning, knowledge representation, planning, natural language processing, perception, and support for robotics.

## History

Artificial intelligence was founded as an academic discipline in 1956, and the field went through multiple cycles of optimism throughout its history, followed by periods of disappointment and loss of funding, known as AI winters.

## Research Methods

To reach these goals, AI researchers have adapted and integrated a wide range of techniques, including search and mathematical optimization, formal logic, artificial neural networks, and methods based on statistics, operations research, and economics.

## Current Development Goals

Some companies, such as OpenAI, Google DeepMind and Meta, aim to create artificial general intelligence (AGI) – AI that can complete virtually any cognitive task at least as well as a human.

## Key Applications

AI has been applied across numerous fields, including:
- Astronomy to analyze increasing amounts of available data for classification, regression, clustering, forecasting, generation, discovery, and the development of new scientific insights, such as discovering exoplanets and forecasting solar activity.
- Generative artificial intelligence is a subfield of artificial intelligence that uses generative models to generate text, images, videos, audio, software code or other forms of data.

Links: [{"title":"Collaborative intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_intelligence"},{"title":"Adaptive collaborative control - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Adaptive_collaborative_control"},{"title":"Collaborative model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_model"},{"title":"Collaborative network - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative_network"},{"title":"Collaboration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collaborative"},{"title":"Autonomy - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous"},{"title":"Autonomous work group - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Autonomous_work_group"},{"title":"Personal boundaries - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Setting_boundaries"},{"title":"Human–robot collaboration - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Human-robot_collaboration"},{"title":"Kratos XQ-58 Valkyrie - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/XQ-58_Valkyrie"}]

Based on the web search results, here are some key concepts and information about collaborative autonomy:

## Collaborative Autonomy in Collaborative Intelligence

Collaborative autonomy of organisms in their ecosystems makes evolution possible. In the context of collaborative intelligence, collaborative intelligence characterizes multi-agent, distributed systems where each agent, human or machine, is autonomously contributing to a problem solving network.(no content)Collaborative autonomy in collaborative intelligence is a prerequisite for next generation platforms for crowdsourcing. The principle emphasizes that individual differences and autonomy are essential, similar to how evolutionary biologist Ernst Mayr noted that evolution requires individual diversity rather than identical participants.

## Adaptive Collaborative Control

Another important application is adaptive collaborative control, a decision-making approach that enables humans and robots to work together as partners rather than in traditional master-slave relationships.(no content)Unlike conventional robotic systems where humans directly control every action, adaptive collaborative control allows autonomous agents (robots) and human operators to collaborate as peers, sharing decision-making responsibilities to accomplish common goals.

## Autonomous Collaborative Networks

Collaborative networks consist of autonomous, geographically distributed, and heterogeneous entities that collaborate to better achieve common or compatible goals, and the discipline of collaborative networks focuses on the structure, behavior, and evolving dynamics of networks of autonomous entities that collaborate to better achieve common or compatible goals.

Web search results for query: "Swarm robotics"

Links: [{"title":"Swarm robotic platforms - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotic_platforms"},{"title":"Swarm robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_robotics"},{"title":"Ant robotics - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ant_robotics"},{"title":"Swarm (novelette) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_(novelette)"},{"title":"Swarm intelligence - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Swarm_intelligence"},{"title":"Kilobot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Kilobot"},{"title":"S-bot mobile robot - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/S-bot_mobile_robot"},{"title":"Sabine Hauert - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sabine_Hauert"},{"title":"Gerardo Beni - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Gerardo_Beni"},{"title":"IISc Guidance, Control and Decision Systems Laboratory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Mobile_Robotics_Laboratory_at_IISc"}]

## Swarm Robotics

I found comprehensive information about swarm robotics. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Characteristics

Swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots, unlike distributed robotic systems in general.(no content)Swarm intelligence is the collective behavior of decentralized, self-organized systems, natural or artificial.

Key principles of swarm robotics include:

- Robots are autonomous, can interact with their surroundings, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities, do not exploit centralized control, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks.
- Miniaturization is a key factor in swarm robotics, as thousands of small robots can maximize the swarm-intelligent approach through greater individual interactions.

### Inspiration and Origins

Swarm robotics takes inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in honey bee aggregation.(no content)The phrase "swarm robotics" first appeared in 1991, though research began growing in the early 2000s.

### Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places rescue-workers cannot reach safely to explore unknown environments.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks demanding cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding tasks. Additionally, progress has been made in swarm 3D printing, which is particularly useful for producing large structures where traditional 3D printing cannot be utilized due to hardware size constraints.

## Swarm Robotics

I found comprehensive information about swarm robotics. Here's an overview:

### Definition and Characteristics

Swarm robotics emphasizes a large number of robots, unlike distributed robotic systems in general.(no content)Swarm intelligence is the collective behavior of decentralized, self-organized systems, natural or artificial.

Key principles of swarm robotics include:

- Robots are autonomous, can interact with their surroundings, possess local perceiving and communicating capabilities, do not exploit centralized control, and cooperate with each other to accomplish tasks.
- Miniaturization is a key factor in swarm robotics, as thousands of small robots can maximize the swarm-intelligent approach through greater individual interactions.

### Inspiration and Origins

Swarm robotics takes inspiration from nature, such as collective problem solving mechanisms seen in honey bee aggregation.(no content)The phrase "swarm robotics" first appeared in 1991, though research began growing in the early 2000s.

### Applications

A promising use of swarm robotics is in search and rescue missions, where swarms of robots of different sizes could be sent to places rescue-workers cannot reach safely to explore unknown environments.(no content)Swarm robotics can also be suited to tasks demanding cheap designs, such as mining or agricultural shepherding tasks. Additionally, progress has been made in swarm 3D printing, which is particularly useful for producing large structures where traditional 3D printing cannot be utilized due to hardware size constraints.

I've completed the web search for "Path planning." Here are the results:

## Overview

Path planning, also known as motion planning or the navigation problem, is a computational problem to find a sequence of valid configurations that moves the object from the source to destination.(no content)The term is used in computational geometry, computer animation, robotics and computer games.

## Key Approaches

There are several main methodologies for path planning:

1. **Grid-Based Methods**: Traditional grid-based approaches produce paths whose heading changes are constrained to multiples of a given base angle, often resulting in suboptimal paths.

2. **Any-Angle Path Planning**: Any-angle path planning algorithms are pathfinding algorithms that search for a Euclidean shortest path between two points on a grid map while allowing the turns in the path to have any angle.

3. **Sampling-Based Algorithms**: Sampling-based algorithms represent the configuration space with a roadmap of sampled configurations. A basic algorithm samples N configurations in C, and retains those in Cfree to use as milestones. A roadmap is then constructed that connects two milestones P and Q if the line segment PQ is completely in Cfree.

## Real-Time Applications

Real-Time Path Planning is a term used in robotics that consists of motion planning methods that can adapt to real time changes in the environment.

## Multi-Agent Pathfinding

Multi-Agent Pathfinding (MAPF) is an instance of multi-agent planning and consists in the computation of collision-free paths for a group of agents from their location to an assigned target.

Links: [{"title":"Assignment problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Assignment_problem"},{"title":"Generalized assignment problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Generalized_assignment_problem"},{"title":"Hungarian algorithm - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hungarian_algorithm"},{"title":"Linear bottleneck assignment problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Linear_bottleneck_assignment_problem"},{"title":"Job-shop scheduling - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Job-shop_scheduling"},{"title":"Multidimensional assignment problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multidimensional_assignment_problem"},{"title":"Talk:Assignment problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Assignment_problem"},{"title":"Fair random assignment - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fair_random_assignment"},{"title":"Quadratic assignment problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Quadratic_assignment_problem"},{"title":"Activity selection problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Activity_selection_problem"}]

Based on the web search results, here's an overview of the **Task Assignment Problem**:

## Basic Definition

The assignment problem is a fundamental combinatorial optimization problem.(no content)The problem instance has a number of agents and a number of tasks, where any agent can be assigned to perform any task, incurring some cost that may vary depending on the agent-task assignment.

## Problem Goal

The solution is whichever combination of agents and tasks results in the least total cost. In a simple example, a taxi firm has three taxis (agents) available and three customers (tasks) wishing to be picked up, where for each taxi the "cost" of picking up a particular customer will depend on the time taken for the taxi to reach the pickup point.

## Variations

1. **Balanced vs. Unbalanced**: If the total cost of the assignment for all tasks is equal to the sum of the costs for each agent, the problem is called linear assignment, and commonly refers to the linear balanced assignment problem.

2. **Generalized Assignment Problem**: This problem is a generalization where both tasks and agents have a size, each agent has a budget, and it is required to find an assignment where agents do not exceed their budget and total profit is maximized.

3. **Other Variants**: The linear bottleneck assignment problem requires that any agent be assigned to perform any task such that the maximum cost among individual assignments is minimized.

## Solution Approaches

There are many algorithms for finding the optimal assignment in time polynomial in n. The Hungarian algorithm (also known as the Kuhn-Munkres algorithm) is a well-known method for solving assignment problems efficiently.

Based on the search results, here's what I found about aerial robotics:

## Definition and History

The term "aerial robotics" was coined by competition creator Robert Michelson in 1990 to describe a new class of small highly intelligent flying machines.

## Development and Capabilities

Over successive years of competition, these aerial robots grew from vehicles that could barely maintain themselves in the air, to automatons which are self-stable, self-navigating, and able to interact with their environment.

## Competitions and Programs

Several educational programs focus on aerial robotics:

- **International Aerial Robotics Competition (IARC)**: The International Aerial Robotics Competition is a university-based robotics competition held on the campus of the Georgia Institute of Technology, and since 1991, collegiate teams with the backing of industry and government have fielded autonomous flying robots in an attempt to perform missions requiring robotic behaviors not previously exhibited by a flying machine.

- **Aerial Drone Competition**: The REC Foundation manages a drone competition for students in grades 5-12 known as the Aerial Drone Competition, which challenges teams' teamwork, programming skills, drone piloting abilities, and communication.

## Applications

Aerial robots have been used for various specialized tasks, including reconnaissance, search and rescue operations, and autonomous navigation through complex environments.

## Competitions and Programs

Several educational programs focus on aerial robotics:

- **International Aerial Robotics Competition (IARC)**: The International Aerial Robotics Competition is a university-based robotics competition held on the campus of the Georgia Institute of Technology, and since 1991, collegiate teams with the backing of industry and government have fielded autonomous flying robots in an attempt to perform missions requiring robotic behaviors not previously exhibited by a flying machine.

- **Aerial Drone Competition**: The REC Foundation manages a drone competition for students in grades 5-12 known as the Aerial Drone Competition, which challenges teams' teamwork, programming skills, drone piloting abilities, and communication.

## Applications

Aerial robots have been used for various specialized tasks, including reconnaissance, search and rescue operations, and autonomous navigation through complex environments.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title, relation: how paper relates to entity, entity_type: one of task/data/artifact/tool/concept/other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results, relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

6. [pending] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

**Paper Classification:** Survey

The paper "UAV swarms: research, challenges, and future directions" was classified as a **survey** paper because it provides a comprehensive exploration and consolidation of existing research areas rather than proposing new methodologies.

**Triples Extracted (9 total):**

1. **Unmanned aerial vehicle** (artifact) - Core platform for swarm systems
2. **Motion planning** (method) - Used for coordinated path planning in swarms
3. **Assignment problem** (task) - Fundamental challenge for task distribution
4. **Control theory** (concept) - Theoretical foundation for formation control
5. **Artificial intelligence** (concept) - Enhances decision-making and autonomy
6. **Machine learning** (concept) - Improves adaptability of swarm systems
7. **Swarm robotics** (concept) - Foundational principles for coordination
8. **Aerial robotics** (concept) - Technical basis for autonomous flying systems
9. **Collaborative intelligence** (concept) - Enables multi-UAV coordination
